Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997, the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Bill 1997 and the Migration Agents Registration Renewal Charge Bill 1997 it is also my intention to move a second reading amendment which has been prepared for the consideration of the Committee. The opposition is opposing this legislation for a range of reasons. We believe that, five years after Labor established the first migration system to protect the vulnerable and to try to stop the shonks, the crooks and the rorters, the coalition government unfortunately is about to water down the scheme. The migration agents registration scheme .was introduced in 1992 by the Labor Party, aimed at trying to protect people in the community who are vulnerable to exploitation by unscrupulous or incompetent migration agents. Today, unfortunately, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs( Mr Ruddock) is taking the first steps to increase exploitation of the vulnerable. We would respectfully request that the minister read the front page of the latest Weekend Australian. An article there warns about the misuse of our migration scheme by criminal elements. That is of central importance to our consideration of the legislation before the Main Committee for consideration today. In vkw of that article, the Australian community should understand whether the minister can assure this parliament that the steps he is now taking will not lead to further abuse by criminal elements exploiting our migration scheme. The migration agents registration scheme set up by the former minister, Mr Gerry Hand, under Labor, was quickly judged a success and was strengthened following the recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, in June 1995. We believe that the government is now intending to gut the scheme. That is what it is about, gutting the scheme and basically throwing out elements which we believe were clearly intended to make the operation of the migration system in Australia a system based on integrity and, basically, one in tune with the community's needs. To throw out those aspects which made it valuable and useful to the community, to keep the shell and then to have the hide to pretend that the government has kept the scheme is far from acceptable to the Australian community. Self-regulation is asking the stronger parts of this sector to refrain from exploiting their position. It would be nice if it worked. However, the reality on the ground is that mostly it does not work. Did this government not state only a few weeks ago that self-regulation with

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl) Took The Chair At 10.00 A.m.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson (Batman) (10.00 A.m.)
theText: In speaking to the MigrationThursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 10383 respect to the relationship between small business and big business was not a goer? It would seem that, where the government believes that there are votes out in the small business community, it is willing to oppose self-regulation to try to buy back small business's support. But when it comes to protecting the vulnerable in the community with respect to the operation of the migration system in Australia, this is a government which supports deregulation without proper consideration of the consequences of such deregulation. Was this not because, so the government stated, there was a major power imbalance? I think the role of government is to ensure that we try to correct some of those power imbalances from time to time, not only to ensure that there is integrity in the Australian community but also to ensure that all Australians get a fair go and can operate on the basis that there is a government in place that is committed to ensuring that any imbalances in power are corrected as required from time to time. Under the bill before the committee for consideration today, it is proposed to delegate the regulation of migration agents to the Migration Institute of Australia. Perhaps if this body really represented the majority of migration agents, this scheme would have some chance of operation. However, the membership of the Migration Institute of Australia currently is only about 10 per cent of all migration agents. I must say I take exception to endeavours by this organisation in recent weeks to actually seek to negotiate with the voluntary sector fees that they might feel are appropriate for the purposes of registration if they are to obtain the authority as embodied in the bill to operate the migration agents registration scheme in the future. If the scheme is to come into operation, I would have thought that sector ought to be totally excluded from the requirement to pay fees, yet we have these usurpers out in the community seeking to negotiate, even before the bill is properly considered by the Australian parliament, appropriate registration fees. For the Migration Institute of Australia to take over an efficient scheme for the regulation of migration agents, they will need massive assistance from the department. Minister, your government's own review of the migration agents registration scheme conducted by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs in March 1997 found that: The current ... scheme has resulted in the removal from the industry of a number of grossly incompetent or unscrupulous operators who were practising as migration agents prior to its establishment. I also contend that it has succeeded in establishing sufficient barriers to exclude those who have demonstrated a capacity for behaving unethically. Clearly, the role of government is not only about restoring the power balance but also about ensuring that the system operates on the basis of some ethics. The scheme as set up at present works to protect the vulnerable against the greedy, and I think that is exceptionally important. Many people who require assistance on the migration front clearly require special protection and a willingness by a government to actually intervene to ensure they are not exploited and, if anything, ripped off by the greedy in the Australian community. So if the system is working well, why does the government want to change it? Who is pressuring the government to get rid of regulation of the industry? After all, the government's own review also found that the scheme had not adversely affected the competitiveness of the migration advice market. There seems to be no reason to move towards self-regulation other than an ideological reason. 10384 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 I must say from this side of the House that we are not amazed at this approach to issues judging from the government's current consideration of a range of policy issues. It is a government run by ideology, rather than the proper consideration of the impact of those ideological decisions on the Australian community at large-be it with respect to aged care, industrial relations, employment, a willingness to invest in industry policy and support regional Australia or, unfortunately, on this very sensitive issue, migration. The changes, I suggest, must be due to some crass ideological bent-to bash the public sector and contract out whatever you can get your hands on. If anything, it is to reward their mates in the Australian community. That is what it is about. You only have to look not just at this bill and the changes on a range of policy fronts in more recent times but also at the range of appointments across many committees and councils established by the Australian government-be it with respect to sporting activity, employment activity, regional Australia or whatever. It is clearly about rewarding mates. That is what it is about. I also suggest that this is related to the bill currently before the House. It must be so because there is nothing, even in the review which the government bases this bill on, which indicates that self-regulation would be better or even as good as the current system. I understand why some members on the other side of the House get sensitive with respect to these issues. I refer to the fact that the review simply states: There is no basis for public funding of the regulation of the migration advice industry. The entire regulation scheme is currently paid for by registration fees. I might take issue with that but, in any event, who pays does not determine who regulates the agents. A government run regulation system funded by registration fees is perfectly feasible and legitimate. The review also stated that the industry had grown in size, developed a better reputation and had a stronger focus on standards and training. I believe that the issue of training is important. The review states baldly, with no supporting evidence or even argument, that self-regulation is needed to develop industry standards and improve client services. This interesting view immediately follows a paragraph which says that the industry has improved since the advent of the migration agents registration scheme. I The Labor opposition agrees that more training is needed by those who work as migration agents. The bill acknowledges this fact. But, in that context, by cutting funding to the Victorian Immigration Advice and Rights Centre and the Immigration Advice and Rights Centre, the non-profit organisations which provide the bulk of the training, the government has, in effect, cut access to such training which is so fundamentally important to the bill before the House. Agents employed by the voluntary sector represent 21 per cent of all migration agents. Currently, many of these agents are registered but do not pay registration fees. It is proposed by the bill that employees of these agencies pay registration fees. As I have indicated, I object to certain elements that seek to take control of this scheme in the future, that actually seek to engage people in the marketplace to determine registration fees without proper. authority or consideration by this parliament or the minister. Is this a deliberate strategy by the government to undermine the financial viability of the voluntary sector? It is basically about ripping away from those who really try to assist the underprivileged in the community their capacity to look after the people who really need assistance, while, at the same time, looking after their mates in the broader community. Thursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 10385 Those who go to the voluntary agencies-the migrant resource centres, the IARC, the needy in the Australian community. They are those who want to sponsor their parents, their children, their husband or their wife. If the voluntary agencies have to pay registration for their employees and volunteers, they will not be able to afford to provide this very valuable service to the Australian community and, more importantly, to those most in need in the Australian community. The question, therefore, is: in whose interest is it that the poorest of the poor will either have nowhere to go or be forced to pay higher, sometimes exorbitant, fees to the private sector? That is the crux of this bill, forcing the poorest in the Australian community into the hands of the greedy and the exploiters while those who want to bring in someone to take the job of an Australian worker will be able to pay for good advice. Of course they will be able to pay for good advice. I am not saying that all migration agents in the private sector are greedy or unscrupulous by any means. Many of those who support self-regulation do so not because they hope thus to evade scrutiny but for reasons which they see as valid. However, we currently have a good system which provides some protection for consumers, and I would argue that we are obligated to protect it. There is a responsibility on this House to seriously consider that question in this debate today. It is about ensuring that, if you have a good system which provides some protection for consumers, you must seriously consider protecting it and keeping it in place. If anything, the House should be debating how we improve it, how we strengthen it, not how we rip it apart. Let us, as proposed by the bill, ensure that migration agents undertake some training each year to upgrade their skills. On the whole, migration advice cannot be controlled by market driven competition. It should be beyond market driven competition. It is not about selling apples or pears; it is about looking after people, looking after the needy in the Australian community. It is not about dollars and cents; it is about people who need assistance. Most of those who use migration agents, as I have said, basically use them on only one occasion-to apply for a family member or a spouse to come here. There really is not an opportunity to shop around. It is often at a time of desperate need. The aim of the registration scheme is to protect the Australian community against the activities of unscrupulous agents aiming to rip off the community, not just their clients. Whenever an agent helps a client lie on a form, he is rorting the system. We should not forget that fact because we all see those types of cases come across our desks. I must say that there is generally on both sides of the House a commitment to ensuring that those types of people are not allowed to rort the system. We also go out of our way to expose those clien-s and agents involved in seeking to rort and destroy a system that is basically held up in the international community as being a decent migration system. Every fake marriage, I suggest, is an abuse of our hospitality. Make no mistake, migration agents have arranged fake marriages for clients. They have in the past and they will continue to do so in the future. Every time a prostitute is brought in on a visitors visa, and then applies for permanent residence, the Australian community is rorted; it is being ripped off. Make no mistake, migration agents have arranged this for their clients. They are to be condemned. 10386 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 Every time a business migrant moves funds into Australia for a strictly limited period, and then moves them out again, the Australian migration system is being abused. As I have said, there are good and bad migration agents. But every time one of these migration agents absolutely rorts the Australian system, then it places further obligation on this parliament to ensure that the system in place is able to control the capacity of those rorters to undermine the integrity of the migration system in Australia. Every time a criminal from overseas comes into this country with the help of someone here, we are being exploited and our safety is being put at risk, as reported in the Weekend Australian of last weekend. The migration agents registration scheme aims to weed out these unscrupulous, criminal agents, and so it ought. The system ought to be protected, it should be strengthened and it ought to have the support of both sides of the House. By gutting the system you are making it easier for the unscrupulous to function. That is what it is about: making it easier for the criminal elements to come into Australia, making it easier for those who want to rort the system amongst the migration agents-and it is not all of them-to actually undermine the integrity of the migration system in Australia. I am not saying that the current disciplinary procedure is ideal. However, self-regulation will not deal at all with the crooks and the rorters. And that is what some of these migration agents are, they are crooks and rorters, they are un-Australian, and they are working against the best interests of Australia as a nation both domestically and internationally. We do not object to setting up a mediation process to deal with consumer complaints. That can be done without self-regulation, and the minister knows that as well as I do. The opposition fears that self regulation would be a backward step and may lead, in actual fact, to deregulation. Minister, you know, and every MP in this House knows, that electorate staff have quite enough work to do without returning to the bad old days of trying to sort through misleading, wrong and illegal advice to would be migrants and their sponsors. More importantly, those hard cases often land on our desks after unscrupulous migration agents have ripped off ordinary people in need, charged exorbitant fees, misled them as to their capacity to assist them on a range of migration issues, and then, having ripped them off, basically said that it is the government's fault-blame the government irrespective of who was in power: 'It's not our fault, you go and see your local federal member of parliament, they are to blame-not me, the migration agent; I have just taken your dollars and run, and I will continue to work one step ahead of you with money in my pocket while you and your family suffer.' Those who are competent and caring agents-the majority, I suggest-have nothing to fear from the current system. The current system is for their benefit because it is about ensuring that those decent agents-as against the crooks and rorters-are out there in the Australian community with a respect and a capacity to operate in a proper way. But the community as a whole has a lot to lose from the dismantling of the safeguards put in place to weed out the shonks and crooks and rorters. That is our fear about the bill before the House today-we go down the deregulation path and it can potentially lead to the shonks, the crooks and the rorters getting the upper hand, unfortunately, with respect to the operation of a system which is basically aimed at assisting the needy in the Australian community. On that basis, as I indicated at the outset, I move: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "the House declines to give the Bill a second reading, and: Thursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 10387 (l) deplores the Government's proposal to self-regulate the migration advice industry, being of the view that this will open the way to the most unscrupulous agents to exploit migrants' vulnerability and lack of knowledge; (2) condemns the Government for proposing that voluntary agencies pay registration fees and regards this action as a deliberate strategy to undermine the service delivery of the voluntary sector; (3) notes that under the self-deregulation proposal there will be no overall monitoring authority and that consumer rights and protection will be marginalised as the decision makers are also members of the industry association, with no independent overseer to review any decision made; (4) notes that the reduction in the time allowed to lodge an objection reveals the Government's disastrous failure to ensure a high standard of character, professionalism, expertise and accountability within the profession and that this will further compound the barriers for consumers to complain, as many who have grounds to will be from non-English speaking backgrounds and will require extra time in order to respond to a nomination; and (5) is of the view that arrangements should be introduced to continue the present arrangements". Ms GAMBARO (Petrie) (10.20 a.m.)-Thank you for the opportunity to speak today on the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Bill 1997, the Migration Agents Registration Renewal Charge Bill 1997 and the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997. This legislation is design-d to further enhance the migration program and focuses on the move towards self-regulation for the migration advice industry. Essentially, the bill is about consumer protection and ensuring that those in need of immigration assistance will have the confidence they need to get a service based on the minimum standard of quality, and that they will be protected. It also ensures that the service is competitively priced and that those seeking that advice will have the opportunity to get redress of a service which may be incompetent or unscrupulous. The need for protection in this particular service industry arises because of the extraordinary vulnerability of those who seek to make use of the service. The member for Batman( Mr Martin Ferguson) is not really concerned about the vulnerability of people. He speaks about protecting people who are unable to protect themselves and, clearly, this bill is about protecting those people. I would also like to note for the information of the member for Batman that the government is currently giving more money-some $5 million a year for the next four yearsthrough a grant scheme to help those people most in need, particularly refugees. This vulnerability is partly due to consumers lacking skills and knowledge in this area, and this was noted in a 1995 report by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. That report acknowledged the adverse consequences which could flow if people received inadequate or inaccurate advice-the most serious being that the applicants could lose their chance to qualify for a visa or to stay in Australia-so the federal government has long been aware that there have existed inadequacies and loopholes in the present regulatory migration advice system. It is amazing to hear the member for Batman speak about migration agents in the way that he has, implying somehow that all migration agents act with impropriety. The experience that I have had in the industry is that there are good and honourable people providing good advice and high quality counsel and care for their clients. It was incredible to hear him slur the industry the way that he has today. Mr Ted Grace-There are some crooks. that the majority of agents behave with impropriety. I find those views he expressed here today offensive; I am sure that many migration agents have high integrity. One of them, the former

speaker: Ms Gambaro
theText: There are crooks in any industry, but the member for Batman is implying10388 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 member for my seat, the Honourable John Hodges, would find those views very offensive. I know that the previous member for Petrie has an outstanding reputation in this field in Queensland. It is also important to note that early in June 1996, we commissioned a review of the migration agents registration scheme-and I have this booklet here with me today. The terms of reference were agreed to by both the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs( Mr Ruddock). It was the first regulatory arrangement to be reviewed by the Commonwealth as part of the competition principles agreement which were reported in March of this year. The bill is in response to this very comprehensive review. I would like to highlight who was on that particular review. We had some rather outstanding people on that review. You could not get a more balanced group of people. We had Mr Ian Spicer, the Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry; Pamela O'Neil, Chairperson of the Migration Agents Registration Boardof the Australian Trade Practices Reporter; Cheryl Webster, a grant-in-aid worker for Careforce for the Anglican Home Mission; the Honourable John Hodges, whom I have mentioned: a former member of this House and very well respected on both sides, and Queensland State President of the Migration Institute of Australia, who has worked for many years in this role as a former minister in this area; and Pauline Mathieson, a national committee member of the Migration Institute of Australia. All these people worked very diligently on the report, and you could not get a more balanced group of people. In light of today' s debate, it is worthwhile highlighting some of their key recommendations, and I would like to do that now. They reported that the migration agents registration scheme must improve its competency standards. This is what it is all about. It is about competency and doing the job right, particularly in relation to entry level training. It is important to stress that. They said that higher entry standards were needed in the restructuring of registration and the accreditation process. What is wrong with an accreditation process and having a higher standard? They reported that the registration fee scheme should reflect those particular competency skills; that legal practitioners who provide assistance should be required to register as migration agents; and that provision should also be made for an industry-run complaints resolution service. The committee said that serious consideration also needed to be given to options necessary for the industry to achieve self-regulation and to develop an industry standard. The report went on to outline the three models of regulation. The first was voluntary self-regulation, working through mechanisms, including setting membership criteria which guaranteed that its members met set competency and ethical standards, and adopting disciplinary procedures to deal with members who breached the code. That is very important. When we look at a number of industries that are also increasing their level of competency, why does this industry have to be excluded from that? They should have a well-developed system and a code of competency and conduct. Other mechanisms were the adoption of a complaints resolution scheme to resolve

theText: Also we had Mr Ian Tonkin, a Sydney barrister and consultant editorThursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMI1TEE 10389 complaints between members and consumers, and the sponsorship of entry-level courses and continuing education. The second model was self-regulation. This model would see the power to register fall within the precincts of the Migration Act under the auspices of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. The final model discussed was that of co-regulation, which focused on the linkages between the government and the industry to regulate the industry. But it was concluded that the migration advice industry still needs to mature in order to achieve true self-regulation. With this in mind, the bill reflects the government's decision to introduce a form of statutory selfregulation for a period of two years, set to commence in March 1998. This bill provides for the appointment of a Migration Institute of Australia as the migration agents registration authority, which will have statutory back-up and departmental assistance, particularly in the area of financial accountability. The referral of instances of unregistered practice and fraud will also fall within the scope of this particular authority, and it includes provisions in relation to performance, financial accountability and also complaints handling. The amendments geared towards monitoring the competency of agents are being spearheaded by the mandatory requirement for all persons, including lawyers, seeking to practise as migration agents to be registered. As well as the introduction of an annual registration renewal, there will now be a requirement for proof, on application for renewal, of continuing professional development, which includes keeping abreast of the most up-to-date regulations, legislation and other migration requirements. Clearer and more stringent registration will also be set for agents working in the voluntary sector, and that is for agents who do not charge clients a fee. There are some very good people in the voluntary sector who provide good advice. But there are also people in the voluntary sector who need to ensure that they maintain their level of accreditation and give good advice to people-because giving bad advice can have absolutely monumental consequences. The scheme will now include assistance to be provided by persons seeking to sponsor or to monitor another person for a visa. The term 'immigration assistance' will be clarified so as to not include assistance provided by travel agents or translation and interpretation service providers. All of these measures are designed to better streamline applications by persons who seek to register as migration agents-and what is wrong with that?-as well as to protect the applicants. In the areas of disciplinary measures and dispute resolution, the most significant amendment is that disciplinary matters involving lawyers and agents will now be referred to the relevant professional bodies, which are the most appropriate bodies to deal with these issues. Also, the Migration Agents Registration Authority will be able to refer parties in dispute for mediation, and there will be an enhancement of the relevant offence provisions to bring them into line with the Commonwealth policy on criminal law, which is a very good measure. It is proposed to introduce a registration fee for those agents operating in the voluntary sector. This has been found to be necessary as at present the absence of a fee for those in the voluntary sector sometimes results in cross-subsidisation in that private sector. To offset the difficulty that those in that sector will have in meeting the costs of registration, the government is going to impose a much lower fee. Also, the Migration Institute of Australia will be authorised to collect fees on behalf of the Commonwealth as a more efficient collection measure. 10390 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 OctoberÂ· 1997 With the aim of the program being to progress towards self-regulation, there will.also be measures to ease its introduction over two years. Agents working in the voluntary sector will have a reasonable time to pay any new charges and agents who are already registered as agents wiIl have two years from the commencement date of this scheme to meet continuing professional development requirements. The migration advice industry, on the whole, has a very significant role to play. It is essential for the future development of an efficient and streamlined immigration program in this country that these measures be implemented to ensure that there is a competent, affordable, ethical and reputable migration advice industry. Not only is this for the protection of the industry's consumers and the community as a whole, but it is also necessary in order to complement the other wide ranging legislative and administrative initiatives that the government has already introduced into the migration program. These initiatives form a very tightly controlled package which will be monitored closely in order that the program be more efficient and be more effectively serving both migrants and the Australian people. The government should be commended for comprehensively addressing these broader issues within the program and for its continued commitment to improving the migration program. Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997, the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Bill 1997, and the Migration Agents Registration Renewal Charge Bill 1997. I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Batman( Mr Martin Ferguson), the shadow minister. Before those opposite get too excited about some of the things I am going to say about migration agents, let me make the caveat that I know there are good and bad in every community and that not all migration agents are crooks who rip people off. I ani going to speak about a couple of bad examples I know of because they are the only examples I know about. That is not surprising because many of the simple migration cases go through without ever first going to a member of parliament. We do not hear about the simple cases. It is the really difficult cases that go to migration agents. The almost impossible cases go there, and therein lies the difficulty. I enjoyed the speech of the honourable member for Petrie (Ms Gambaro). She said at the outset that this legislation was all about extra consumer confidence. I take issue with that because I do not think it is going to give the consumer any confidence at all. I think it is going to open up an area that unscrupulous operators will be able to get into and they will operate without the protection that is there now. Every member of parliament, just as they have five or six basket cases who come and see them when the full moon is out, has their five favourite stories concerning migration rip-offs. As I said before, we hear of these because it is the really difficult cases that go to migration agents. As the member representing the IIIawarra and its large ethnic population, so much of my time and my office staff's time is taken up with migration cases and always they are the very, very difficult ones. The migration agents registration scheme has been in operation since 1992. It was created in response to an alarming number of complaints from the community that unqualified and unscrupulous migration advisers were working in the field. I must put it on the public record that I have always been opposed to migration agents. It is no use saying that it was a
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hollis (Throsby) {10.32 A.m.)
theText: I rise to speak in this debate on the MigrationThursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 10391 government that I was part of which introduced it. I was opposed to the scheme even when we introduced it, and argued against it. NothingI have seen of migration agents' operations over the years has convinced me to think less unkindly of many-not all-of these people. Yet the government is going to make migration agents subject to self-regulation. I just cannot believe that: if any group should not be let loose on the public, migration agents are that group. My personal and long held view is that migration agents should be abolished. I think that they mislead and they build up false expectations. You only have to look at the advertisements in the weekend Sydney papers-I do not know about those in other states-to see that there are always as such as those I have taken up with successive ministers for immigration, saying that these as mislead. They say, in effect, 'Having problems with migration? See us'-all these issues. And people do go there and see them. Migration agents can do no more, and most often do far less, than the local federal member of parliament. As the shadow minister has said-and I will illustrate this later-many of these cases that start off with migration agents end up, after the fee is paid, on our desk. It is we members of parliament who have to do the work. I have no objection to that. I think that is one of the roles of a member of parliament, and that is why I have always been opposed to migration agents. I know that each of my colleagues can, and I suspect will, tell their stories about migration agents during this debate. I have had several shams operating in my area. One concerned Chinese immigrants, who would go to a lawyer who was also registered as a migration agent. This lawyer, after taking their money, would then start harassing my office about approaching the minister about a whole lot of other things. It was so blatant that the agent was pocketing the money and then wanting my office to do all the work that my office decided that we would have no dealing with that lawyer at all. Every time that lawyer would ring up or get people to ring up, we would say, 'Are you dealing with So-and-so?' If they said yes, we would say, 'He has taken on that role for you. Let him follow it through.' My office made it clear to these constituents that in future they would be required to come and see us before going to a migration agent if they expected us to take up the case. My objection was that they were paying this agent $5,000 but all they got for their $5,000 was a telephone call from the lawyer to my office, putting the case on my desk. It is just unbelievable. This is my argument with migration agents. They are in a business first and foremost; they must promise success to get people to part with their money. Yet they are fully aware that many of the cases they take on have no chance of success. I do not know why people are saying that migration agents give them all this advice. Many of the cases have absolutely no chance of success. We all know how difficult it is to migrate to Australia today. Over two million people apply to migrate to Australia every year, and what do we take-60,000 or 70,000 people. There are just so many cases that it is just absolutely hopeless. My policy has always been, in the 14 years I have been a member of parliament, that we will fight to the nth degree on a case. We will go and make representation and, if necessary, see the minister. We will make all the representations. But we are always very frank with everyone about migration problems or migration chances. When people come to see us, we go through the points score with them. We ask them all the usual questions-any remaining relatives there, the whole thing-and often there is absolutely no chance. Members would know the points system: if it is very close we can say, 10392 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 'Okay, we will have a look at your language skills. We will have a look at your qualifications,' and we will say, 'Yes, we will take your second cousin into account. You have an extended family.' We go through all these things with them. But when there are 30 or 40 points missing, even though people cry in your office and so on you have to be honest with them, because sooner or later you are going to face these people and say, 'I did everything I could. I went and saw the minister three times, I did this and I did that. But there was no chance.' Why build their hopes up for 12 or 18 months? It is much better to tell them first of all. We go through the points system; we do everything. We always say to people, 'If you really want me to write to the minister or to go and see the minister, I will. But this will probably delay it, because they will have to get the file down from Rockdale'-or wherever they keep it in Sydney-and things like that. I have always believed that if a constituent says, 'You are my local member. I insist that you do this,' or, 'that you write to the minister,' I should write to the minister or do whatever it is. But, in honesty, I tell them, 'Yes, I will write to the minister, but I have got to tell you honestly that your chances are Buckley's. It might change later on or the policy might be different' -and I go through all of the reasons why we are only taking so few people into Australia. We have to tell them. I believe it is wrong and immoral to build up people's expectations falsely, knowing that there is no chance of meeting what are very stringent immigration requirements. Only two weeks ago, I think it was, I had a Macedonian business person come in to see me. There are a lot of Macedonian people in my electorate. This Macedonian gentleman had a 44year-old female cousin here on a visitors visa. He came in to see me. because, as he told me, he wanted her status changed from visitor to permanent resident. First of all, I said, 'There is absolutely no chance. The best you can do is to get her to go back and then apply.' I went on with all the arguments about jumping the queue if they did it. I said, 'Whatever government it is, whether it is the Labor Party or the Liberal Party, the minister will not change. They are vcry hard on this, for right reasons.' I said if they went back and then applied, we would watch it through. I went through the whole procedure. I asked about the cousin's qualifications, but there were none; I asked about language ability, where the bulk of the family lived and about health; I said that they would have to have a police check-all the things we do. It was obvious that cven on the most generous interpretation this woman would not meet the requirements to migrate to Australia-not least in that she had a husband in Macedonia, yet she wanted to stay here. I just said, 'We can't do this.' I said that, even if she went back to Macedonia and then applied and came out, it would be very difficult. But there was Buckley's chance of getting her status changed from visitor to permanent resident. My constituent let me know that money was no object. He said, 'Colin, it doesn't matter how much it costs.' I said, 'It is not really the money. It is not a case of whether you can support the woman here or not. There are requirements and laws, and if she does not meet the requirements you have got Buckley'S chance.' It was not a question of money or of his financial support of the cousin, but there was no way that the cousin, on my reading of the points, could migrate to Australia. It was obvious that the person absolutely did not believe me. Rightly or wrongly, I do not have many Liberal members of parliament in my area. I used to have a Liberal senator there, and any time people were in a difficult situation like that I Thursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 10393 always said to them, 'Go and see Senator Baume' -as it used to be; he had his office in Wollongong. 'Don't take my word for it. Go and see Senator Baume.' SoI said to this person, because money was no object to him, 'Why don't you see a Liberal member? If you think that I am just saying this because I am a member of the opposition or I do not want to take on the case or something like that, go and see one of the government members in our area or in Sydney. But I suspect that that person would come to exactly the same conclusion as mine.' The plot thickened, however, because that guy then told me that he had been to see a migration agent who suggested he come and see me. Do you know how much he paid? He paid that migration agent $12,000. Twe:-e thousand dollars he paid and do you know why he parted with that money? I actually said to him, 'Look, mate, you might as well have taken that $12,000 out there on the road and stuck a match to it and burnt it for all the success you are going to get.' That migration agent had promised that person that he would guarantee that that cousin would get permanent residency in Australia. He had given a guarantee. I said, 'Did you get it in writing?' He said, 'No'. I said, 'Mate, before you ever part with money like that, you get something in writing from that migration agent.' He had given $12,000 because the migration agent had promised that they would get that person in. He just could not get that person into Australia. The agent had said he would pull out all stops. I said, 'What do you think that person can do that I cannot do as a member of parliament? I can go and see the minister; I can go through the whole thing.' He said, 'Colin, he promised me that he would get them permanent residency.' It is outrageous that these kinds of promises are made and that such huge fees are taken from these people with so little result at the end of the day. The proposal to self-regulate the migration agents industry is yet another blow to those people who are exploited and vulnerable to the snake oil charms of those expensive advisers. The legislation allows the most unscrupulous migration agents to stay in business, to make their unending promises, to keep sucking money out of people who are vulnerable and lack'the knowledge of the processing of attempts to remain in Australia. The legislation provides for the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs( Mr Ruddock) to appoint a Migration Institute of Australia, which will be the authority which registers migration agents. Some of the migration institute's responsibilities will be to register applicants and take disciplinary action against registered agents. On page 44 of the bill's explanatory memorandum, it is made clear that the MIA preparation task for its new responsibilities will be quite extensive. It says that the MIA will need to 'prepare to take on a role of industry regulator, including building its membership base'. At this time the MIA is a small organisation with a membership not at all representative of the migration agent industry. At the time of the MARS review in 1996, the MIA membership comprised only 12 per cent of migration agents who dealt mainly with migration registration. I know that when the shadow minister mentioned sham marriages some people objected. I have seen sham marriages down in my area and I tell you one other area that we ought to look at when we are looking at sham marriages. We ought to look at the marriage celebrants. I had a marriage celebrant in my area and he was marrying people so that they could stay here in Australia. They did not have the requirements and I got him into my office and I went through the whole thing with him. I said, 'Look, this person was here on a visitors visa or this and that. They don't meet the requirements. Why did you perform this marriage ceremony?' He said to me, 'Because there is nothing in the regulations that says that I, as a marriage 10394 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 celebrant, should check the requirements of people staying here. You check whether they are married or not. You check all sorts of things, but you do not have to check their status in Australia.' They are in Australia as a visitor or whatever it is and they will marry them under the false belief that they will then be allowed to stay in Australia. I am most concerned also about the attack on the voluntary system. In my area, we have the Illawarra Migrant Resource Centre, which does a lot of good work. We often work very closely with them on some of these cases. Indeed, we sometimes ask people to go in and sethem when it is a really difficult case and we know there is going to be no success. We ask them to confirm our reading of the situation. As I understand it-and I could be wrong herewhere in the past only one fee has been charged, now each person given advice in that migrant resource centre is going to have to pay the fee. They are not going to be able to do it. I did hear I think it was the member of Petrie say that is was a lower fee. I am not quite sure how much it is, but I mean, this is going to put thehave had with the migrant resource centre on this, they are very worried that, if each person is going to be subjected to a fee, then that is going to put them out of that business and they will not be able to afford to pay that fee, especially given the cuts that have been imposed on the migrant resource centres recently. They are not going to be able to afford to pay that fee, therefore they are going to be put out of work. We are going to force these people into the agents who can afford to pay the fee-the wealthy ones. As I have always said, not every . migration agent is a rip-off merchant. But, my God, there are enough of them who are rip-off merchants to set alarm bells ringing in my mind. I think this is a disastrous step and this is why I so strongly support the amendment moved by the shadow minister. a contribution will be made in accordance with the standing orders. I object strongly to rowdy interjections across the chamber and I advise my intention to enforce the standing orders. I call the honourable member for Deakin. the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997, the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Bill 1997, and the Migration Agents Registration Renewal Charge Bill 1997, will provide certainty and security to some of the most vulnerable people in our society, Australia's would be or newly arrived migrants and their families. I think it is fair to say that all of us who are speaking on this bill recognise the need for such security and for such need to protect the vulnerable in our society. The problems are well known to us. They have certainly been elucidated quite well today by speakers from both sides. There is disagreement about the solution. With that in mind, I, too, rise today to support the government's legislation but oppose the amendments from the member for Batman( Mr Martin Ferguson). In my electorate of Deakin, one in four people, a total of 29,000, were born overseas. Recent evidence suggests their proportion is rising. Over half of Deakin's migrants are from non-English speaking countries such as Vietnam, China, Greece and Italy. English is not the main language spoken at one in six homes in my electorate. One in 10 local migrants speaks English not well or not at all. These people faced immense challenges as they prepared to move to this country or in sponsoring their relatives to join them.
