speaker: Mr Lloyd (Robertson) (12.09 P.m.)
theText: I am pleased today to have the opportunity to speak10414 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 The aspects of youth suicide seminar was convened on 28 February 1997, in order to gather information such as that collected at the central coast suicide summit to give committee members a comprehensive overview of the issues involved. The seminar also provided an invaluable opportunity for peak health and community groups, local organisations, youth workers, academics and professionals to exchange information about the suicide prevention programs throughout Australia. Among the invited guests was Mr Eric Trezise. At that seminar, I had the opportunity of introducing Mr Trezise to the Prime Minister( Mr Howard). Mr Trezise had the opportunity to put his views and his concerns about the situation on the central coast directly to the Prime Minister. I would also like to put on the record that I was a participant at the seminar and found it very valuable and informative. Unfortunately, my nameÂ· was omitted from the report. The Central Coast community is not standing still on this issue. We are not waiting for governments to take the lead. As a community, we are taking the lead. Only recently, I attended the launch and had the opportunity of addressing the audience at the launch of the Central Coast Suicide Safety Network. The Central Coast Suicide Safety Network was launched by the Premier of New South Wales, the Hon. Bob Carr, who has agreed to become the patron of the network. The launch was attended by over 300 concerned community leaders, as yet another step in the fight against youth suicide and suicide in general on the central coast. The aims of the Suicide Safety Network are: to raise awareness of the tragic loss of life to suicide in the central coast region of Australia, with emphasis on all age groups; to make the public and the governments-local, state and federal-aware of the needs for a collaborative and concerted attack on this problem; to draw attention to the factors which play a role in attempted suicide and to foster appropriate prevention and support initiatives; to highlight the suffering of those bereaved by suicide and those distressed by attempted suicide, and to encourage self-help groups; to install a direct access telephone service responding to suicide crisis calls; to establish a psychological and sociological autopsy suicide case review panel; to promote trial and pilot programs aimed at reducing the incidence of suicide and attempted suicide amongst all age groups; and to solicit funding and resources to enable these programs to become reality. You can see that the aims of this network are very comprehensive. One of the major contributing factors identified in the report Aspects of youth suicide is isolation and loneliness. In paragraph 41 of the report, the committee was told that any kind of youth support service must be targeted appropriately, otherwise young people will not access the service. Professional centres requiring appointments during school or work hours, or where a payment is required, will not meet the needs of many young people. Telephone lines, such as Lifeline, are also a valuable resource as they can provide 24-hour assistance and provide immediate counselling and contact to those young people at a time when they are most vulnerable to suicide. I am aware that under the Here for Life program the government has allocated over $1 million for improving communication networks among suicide prevention workers and coordinating information dissemination. In the 1996-97 budget, under the national youth suicide strategy, the government has provided over $19 million over three years to be spent in this area, including $6 million to Lifeline and Kids Helpline for the telephone counselling services. This is an admirable initiative and is to be commended. Current funding for youth suicide prevention amounts to $30 miIIion, and the committee recognised that while this amount is Thursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 10415 significant much more still needs to be done. This includes research, coordination, education and counselling services. In paragraph 55 the committee recognised that consideration needed to be given to the possible reallocation of some of the existing funds. We on the Central Coast of New South Wales have been advocating for some time the establishment of a specific suicide prevention advisory phone counselling service for the Central Coast. It has been identified by a number of those who have been affected by this tragedy that the most effective way that the Central Coast community can help stop this tragic waste of human life is to have this specific phone counselling and assistance service. We have the premises, we have the trained staff, we have the volunteers on the Central Coast who can provide this service. What we do need is government funds to fund the service. I would appeal to the Minister for Family Services, Warwick Smith, and the Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, to consider looking at our submission from the Central Coast for the provision of this telephone counselling service. I have already had discussions with Dr Wooldridge and, of course, like every Australian, he is concerned about the suicide problem that we have in Australia, not just the youth suicide problem. Whilst youth suicide is receiving a great deal of coverage, and it is a high profile concern to everybody, there is a major problem-and we have identified this on the Central Coastwith men aged between 25 and 45 who are not coping with the stresses of life. They are not coping with the responsibilities, as they see it, of raising families, of mortgages or losing jobs. They are what we call on the Central Coast the hidden tragedy of suicide. They are the people that cost our community far more than anyone else. The loss of the life of a person in the prime of their life, when they have children or family responsibilities and work, and the loss and tragedy for the community that are caused by someone in that age bracket taking their life are immense. It is something that we on the Central Coast wish to highlight-not only the youth suicide program. I know that Dr Wooldridge is looking at what we are saying and at the submissions that we are putting up. Very shortly I will be bringing a committee from the Central Coast, including our local coroner, Bryan Wilson, and Mr Trezise and a number of other leading people in the field, to meet Dr Wooldridge to put f0rward our ideas and our views on tackling this problem again. I have waited a number of weeks to be able to make my comments on this report. It is an excellent report. I know that the government has acted on some of the recommendations and certainly will be acting on more of them. I commend the report to the House. Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report on the seminar into aspects of youth suicide, I would firstly add my words of commendation on the deductions of the report. It is a useful document and the recommendations are of value. I would like also to express a personal appreciation to those people who took part in it. The seminar presenters were diverse and well informed, and they brought forward information, ideas and experiences which were quite valuable. I think that, for those who were not aware of this problem, the day was a useful exercise in encapsulating some of the issues. I say 'some' of the issues because there is a very real danger that we start to treat suicide as a kind of disease that is preventable-that we actually look at some ways of inoculating people or perhaps immunising them against suicide. There is a real danger that we see it as being something in isolation. In that context, I want to make some comments about some of
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Allan Morris (Newcastle) (12.20 P.m.)
theText: In speaking to the House of10416 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 the issues that are involved in youth suicide, and in suicide in general, so we are dealing with the person in a holistic way. At the seminar and in other forums it has become clear that suicide seems to be a person's statement that their life has no further meaning; there is no further point. For one reason or another, an individual decides that there is no longer a meaningful place for them here on this earth, amongst the people that they have normally been amongst. How those decisions are made and in what context varies enormously, and there is a very great danger that, because we use the same word, we tend to group them as having similar reasons and similar backgrounds. The fact is that they do not. If we look at, for example, sexuality amongst young males, particularly in remote and rural areas, we find that, as we discovered in our parliamentary inquiry into aspects of youth homelessness and from talking to some people in the gay and lesbian community, there is an enormous pressure there, particularly on young men who perhaps conclude that they may have a sexual preference which is not normal in their context and their environment and are therefore alienated. Many of those young men end up in cities and end up suiciding, one way or another. We have to understand that, when a society goes through the kind of changes that we are going through in terms of family breakdowns, there may well be casualties. And the casualties may well be young people who no longer have either a place in the world or a family. In our report on youth homelessness tabled in the previous parliament, we pointed out that some 60 per cent of young people on youth homeless allowance came from single or blended families. In other words, almost two out of three people who were claiming that allowance were from a family that had broken down. . At the same time, we have been watching with great alarm the massive increase in abuse of young people. One can argue about whether we are getting more reporting and whether or not the actual incidence of abuse has changed a lot, because in past years child abuse was not reported in the same way and was not investigated. But the fact is that, since it has been reported and since it has been mandatory, the numbers are increasing every year in a way that is truly alarming. If there is an epidemic in our society, the epidemic is more likely to be child abuse than suicide. Looking at those young people who do suicide and those young people who are homeless, one finds that the incidence of abuse appears to be very high. The fact that we have something like 30,000 confirmed cases of abuse of our young people per year should be a cause of enormous distress to us-as should be the fact that so many people who are committing abuse are not charged or in any way penalised for it. It is not simply paedophilia, currently in the public eye, but all abuse that is much worse. The effect of it in demeaning, demoralising and, in fact, eventually destroying so many young Australians must not be underestimated. Suicide is not necessarily a self-generated conclusion. In so many cases it is generated by what is done to one, and the effect of the loss of esteem, confidence and sense of self that is brought about by acts of abuse on young people is, to my mind, a vast and unrecognised darkÂ· side of our society. As I said, every year the figures come out and they increase year after year. I suppose that those of us who watch that and are concerned about that would recognise the difficulty of definition. We recognise all those complications, but the facts are inescapable: there is a major problem in our society with young people being treated as objects that are able to be abused. Thursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 10417 In .the report that we dealt with in 1995, after a very extensive range of inquiries around the country and submissions and a whole range of discussion.s, I was disturbed-and I still am disturbed-that so many parliamentarians were in fact blaming young people. The difficulty of determining homelessness and abuse is profound, but the risks are so great that most people working in the field tend to take the view that you give the first credibility to the young people themselves. All the evidence would indicate that in the vast majority of cases that is correct. I was therefore somewhat dismayed back in 1995 when members of the now government actually questioned that and actually made the claim in their minority report that they had reservations about the claims for homelessness. In fact they had the idea, which is still current, that our young people fabricate claims for the homelessness allowance. The fact that we are getting 30,000 cases of abuse per year should be grounds enough for every one of us to overcompensate and to be, if you like, totally alert to it. But the fact is that two current ministers and a number of other present government members were, in the previous parliament, saying two things. They were saying, firstly, that they had reservations about the bona fides of claimants; and their second point was, effectively, compulsory mediation. In other words, we should make the young person and the parent, who may well be a step-parent, engage in a process of mediation which would in fact expose the young person to having to confront the person that they were accusing or the person that in many cases was abusing. Of course, what that means is very simple: young people do not report. The whole message there was that the parent was always right. That is still the message. They have translated from opposition into government and have kept the message running, and I think that should be of concern. So, for those people in the government now who are concerned about suicide, I would put it to you that it does not come about by accident; it does not happen as a one-off thing. In so many cases, it is an end result of something else. Another ingredient involved is the question of mental health-and, again, during that inquiry we were alarmed at the evidence brought forward of the incidence of mental health problems amongst our young. The fact is that about 50 per cent of all severe psychiatric illnesses are diagnosed by the age of 19 and the median age for half of our mental disorders is 16; yet, when you look at the expenditure on mental health, you will find that the vast bulk of itsomething like 93 per cent of it-is on adults. In other words, we have a serious problem with the numbers of young people with mental health problems who are not being serviced, who are not getting the attention and support they need. Closely associated-;and, in many cases, linked-with that are the problems of drug and alcohol abuse. . WhatI am trying to suggest is that suicide, particularly youth suicide, is often a matter of their total environment-of their background, of family disruption, of abuse, and eventually the question of identity, esteem and optimism. Abuse and family breakdowns often destroy the identity. Equally, they destroy the esteem. Optimism is another factor in the sense that other matters impact on that. Confidence in one's capacity to play a meaningful role, confidence in one's capacity to have a meaningful relationship, confidence to be a successful parent themselves, in so many young people is lacking. That comes back to the question of economics. Our young people, together with the majority of our older people, see governments and parliamentarians as being preoccupied with economics and not the community. The famous Thatcher statement 'There are no communities, just individuals' echoes very strongly in this situation. If you are the individual that she spoke of and you have been a victim of abuse or of family breakdown, if you are not that clever and not that well educated, 10418 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 then do you exist? The idea that you exist by yourself has been one of the most damaging and destructive elements in our sociological development this century. The fact is that youth suicide is in proportions which should alarm us. However, as I said at the start, we should not see it as a disease in isolation that we cannot prevent. We really must see it as part of something else. Unless we get to the real symptoms and treat them and address them, all the rest is rhetoric and posturing . .I encourage those in the government who have not read the report on youth homelessness to read it because what we uncovered in that report, as did Brian Burdekin, was a sickness in our society of serious proportions. The victims of that sickness were not the adults; they were the young. In many cases those young people survived, and some heroically. I met a young woman who was 14Yz and she had been a prostitute for a year, since she was 13lh. I met another young woman who was a graduate of a university. She had left school at 14 and been a prostitute at 14, but she had come through all that and got educated and gained a degree. There were enormously heroic stories. I also met some people who I do not think are alive any more. I met a young man in a squat who is now dead, who suicided. When one looks at that evidence there is not much point in coming to the end of the thing and saying, 'How can we prevent youth suicide?' because the forces have been laid down in many cases five, 10 or 15 years before, and no-one gave a damn. Maybe they had told somebody but no-one cared, or they were not believed. There were so many cases where young people were sent back to abusive households. There were so many cases where mothers had to choose between their daughters and their then husband or partner. There were so many cases where no-one seemed to give a damn, and the end result is we all get worried about youth suicide. If we do not start worrying a lot sooner and believing these people a lot earlier and understanding them a lot better, we will see a lot more suicides, not fewer suicides. No amount of strategies in documenting, in isolating, in having help lines or anything else, will assistbecause they are all treating the symptoms when we have to treat the cause. We have to get back to understanding what is happening to our young people at an earlier stage, not when they are teenagers. In many cases the causes arise when they are four or five or six or eight years of age. The committee's report is of value to the parliament and the community. It is of even more value when it is linked with its previous report on youth homelessness. I would urge all parliamentarians to look much more closely at not just the issue of suicide but youth trauma, youth development and the family frameworks in which they grow up. report entitled Aspects of youth suicide. I intend to address the extraordinarily high representation that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians make in the national statistics. I do this not to downplay the human tragedy of non-ATSI suicide but to highlight the difference between the ATSI and non-ATSI experience of youth suicide, which should give some indication of how our best efforts might be better directed in combating suicide in anÂ· approach which will recognise the uniqueness of ATSI suicide and self-harm. An indictment of the seriousness of youth suicide is evident in one of the ATSI communities in my electorate which, sadly, currently holds the unfortunate reputation of having the largest number of youth suicides in the country and one of the largest in the world. Standing almost as a monument, and an ongoing reminder to the tragedy of the children in this community,
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Entsch (Leichhardt) (12.35 P.m.)
theText: I am speaking on this occasion about the summaryThursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 10419 is a tree known locally as the hanging tree which, to date, has provided a means to suicide for 20 young people in that community-a frightening statistic by anybody's reckoning. The summary report Aspects of youth suicide points to factors such as age, family separation history, geographic isolation, unemployment, and drug and alcohol use. If these are important factors in increases in suicide amongst Australians, then it would seem that they would be more relevant to ATSI Australians, and I shall address these individually. Suicide rates amongst white Australians remain fairly constant at around 15 to 20 cases per 100,000 Australians from the age of 16 to 75-plus. ATSI suicide, on the other hand, is a problem that is particularly a youth related one. Suicide rates amongst black Australians can be measured in significant numbers from an earlier age of 13. The number rises dramatically to nearly double that of non-ATSI suicide by early adulthood. By mid-adulthood, the rate drops by two-thirds and, surprisingly, further reduces to insignificant numbers by the age of 55. The trauma of divorce or parental separation is a factor in many youth suicides. I guess the official state sanction of family separation would surely have had a greatly increased result, one would imagine. The Bringing them home report demonstrated the dramatic effects that this had on the lives of those that the family separation policy touched. The ratio of urban to non-urban ATSI Australians is roughly 70 to 30 whereas the reverse is the case for non-ATSI Australians. Those in remote and rural areas do notonly suffer from a lack of the many crisis support systems available for those in urban areas but they also suffer, as all members of regional electorates know well, worse standards in terms of infrastructure and opportunity. ATSI unemployment stands at four times the national average, at about 40 per cent. According to leading experts on ATSI suicide in Australia and to the author of Aboriginal health and history, Professor Ernest Hunter, drug use and alcoholism appear to be the most significant immediate causes of suicide. Professor Hunter heads an excellent team of academics with social and preventative medicine based in Cairns in my electorate. The work of this unit is well regarded nationally through its hands-on approach with the larger ATSI population centres improving ATSI health outcomes. Professor Hunter claimed a significant victory recently for Far North Queensland to lead the way in research and training to solve chronic problems facing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health, when a $1.5 million funding allocation to establish a centre of excellence in ATSI health was awarded to a joint submission of the University of Queensland and the Queensland University of Technology, which will conduct much of its work through the social and preventative medicine units in Cairns. According to Professor Hunter, increased vulnerability to suicide was first experienced by young Aboriginal males passing into and through adolescence in the late 1980s. As suicide is an end point-as are also increasing rates of alcohol abuse, self-mutilation, child abuse and domestic violence-much can be learnt by exploring the background factors rather than seeking a cause in the immediate circumstances. We should look at the situation for Aboriginal Australians reaching maturity in the 1980s, which was shaped by the experience of those young adults who were having children through the 1970s. This is a period of tumultuous change, with significant consequences for social roles within Aboriginal Australia. A generation who were young adults at the time of the Commonwealth referendum experienced entry into a cash economy, with unemployment and welfare dependence and increasing access to alcohol, following the legislation of its sale to Aboriginal 10420 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 Australians. Circumstances of continuing social disadvantage and binge drinking provided a context in which the impulsive, aggressive expression of tension resulted in escalating interpersonal violence. This proposition of increasing violence is supported by statistics showing an increase in suicide by violent means. Research by Harrison and Moller conducted in 1994 showed that 93 per cent of Aboriginal suicides resulted from hanging or firearms, compared with 43 per cent of non-Aboriginal deaths, a comparison not shown in the Aspects of youth suicide summary report. The Australian Institute of Suicide Res-arch and Prevention report to the Commonwealth last year showed that those means are also the most lethal. Given the availability of means, with guns being readily available in remote areas and rural settings-and hanging being a matter of opportunity rather than means-and the connection with alcohol, the impulsivity is particularly important. Research conducted by Professor Hunter and others for the National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre in Sydney revealed that impulses to. self harm and suicide were widely experienced by ATSIC.informants, with a moderate association to drinking status. However, acting on those impulses was strongly associated with alcohol, and it was the quantity consumed per drinking occasion rather than the frequency of consumption that predicted past self-harmful or suicidal acts. Rather than being causal in an absolute sense, alcohol appears . to enable the acting out of simmering impulses that may be otherwise better coped with. Sadly, of a more sinister nature, an area of concern is the s,exual abuse of children, a contributing factor no doubt to youth suicide. Unfortunately, this is very prolific in some ATSI communities. Reports that I have received in my office would certainly appear to confirm this. A recorded high incidence of sexually transmitted diseases, particularly in very young children, in some of the communities undoubtedly confirms this factor. I have had evidence received in my office of children as young as six and seven with very serious advanced forms of sexual disease. Clearly, this is a major factor with regard to the well-being of that child. I feel that this is an area that really needs to be explored a lot more and to be dealt with very firmly and harshly if we have any way of being able to give those kids any sort of future. Unfortunately, it is because it is of a very sensitive nature that the issue tends to be swept under the carpet. Unless it is addressed in a more open forum, along with the other contributing factors like substance abuse and unemployment, the issue of youth suicide will never ever be resolved. Thirty years after the Commonwealth referendum, the tensions experienced by young adult Aborigines in relation to the wider society are probably greater than those experienced by their parents at a similar age. We are now at an historic point with the ability to accept these facts and seriously address them. The acceptance by the government of this report gives the opportunity for experts in the field to have a direct line of communication with the highest levels of the decision-making process. With this prospect, I certainly commend the report to the House with two qualifications. Firstly, I would be greatly concerned should the priority 3 recommendation that an immediate review of current funding and redirection of some funds to a more appropriate and better targeted program lead to a reduction of the level of funding for ATSI suicide prevention, which currently stands at $1.058 million out of a $32 million budget. Secondly, I support the recommendation of the report that a national advisory council be established to provide strategic advice to the minister and government on youth suicide Thursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 10421 prevention and related matters. But I would recommend that this council must contain an expert on ATSI suicide, given the uniqueness of the ATSI situation. Youth suicide is certainly a blight on our society-a cancer, if you like-and it is clear that it crosses all cultural boundaries. Our youth are our future and it is essential that we as a society do all in our power to address this tragedy. I will, of course, continue to fully support all efforts and initiatives in this regard. Ms GAMBARO (Petrie) (12.47 p.m.)-I rise today to also address the topic which has become so significant. There are very few communities that have not come to grips with the devastation of youth suicide. The incidence of suicide has now reached most unacceptable levels, particularly in regional areas and particularly with respect to males. However, the increase in the rate of suicide in cities should not be minimised. According to a recent publication from the Australian Institute for Suicide Research and Prevention, there are upwards of 2,500 deaths recorded as suicide each year. Queensland and Tasmania have the highest incidences of suicides. A report recently released by the Queensland government indeed confirms this very sad fact. However, even more disturbing is that for every successful suicide there are up to 300 female and 50 male unsuccessful attempts. In my own electorate of Petrie, as indeed in Australia, there are families who have known the pain and suffering of having someone close to them commit suicide. Recently, I hosted a breakfast in Margate, which Professor Baume and the member for Fisher( Mr Slipper) convened. Over 100 people attended this breakfast. It was particularly sad at the end of the breakfast when I was speaking to a number of people who had been touched by this particular problem. A mother in tears approached me. She was absolutely devastated by the death of her son 12 months previously. She was still in a period of denial and did not understand why he had taken his life. But she felt reassured by coming along to the breakfast and she thanked me enormously for organising the breakfast. It gave her great comfort and reassurance that there was nothing that she could have done and no way that she could have predicted that he would take his life. I was able to then put her in touch with a support group of parents who are able to meet on a regular basis and discuss the issues of youth suicide. The most tragic thing is that the people who are left behind are the ones that suffer for many years afterwards not knowing if there was something that they somehow could have done to prevent their young ones taking their lives. It is the not knowing that haunts them for the rest of their lives. It is important to emphasise that this touches everyone from family to friends. Quite often, the friends that are left in their wake and their family are the ones that really do need the help the most. But it is an issue that does affect the lives of families, not only in the Redcliffe areas I have mentioned, in Deception Bay, but throughout Australia. We cannot ignore it as a community and we cannot really take it very lightly. We have a responsibility as a community not to trivialise this or ignore it, because it has very great social ramifications. It is an issue that we see quite a lot. We see it in the media, in programs like 60 Minutes, and in publications. We even have the misfortune now to see it on the Internet. On one occasion, I heard Professor Baume speak of the role of the Internet and what young people use it for these days. They use it as a forum to communicate with each other on suitable and appropriate measures of suicide and they actually give each other tips on the most effective ways to commit suicide. It is disturbing to see that. There are thousands of hit sites on the 10422 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 Internet that deal with this. It is quite a blight on our society that the Internet is being used by young people to communicate these things. As with any tragic death, the ramifications of suicide are very widespread but, unlike other tragic deaths, suicide brings with it great sadness, disbelief and guilt. As I mentioned, family and friends are the ones who find it very hard to understand. Like ripples in a pond, these deaths, by their very nature, cannot fail to affect everyone in the community. One thing I have noticed is that, if there are cases of suicide in families, it tends to be an intergenerational thing. There are certainly issues that never get resolved in the first place. It gets buried away under the carpet or in the cupboard. People do not speak about it, and intergenerational suicide is a very common thing. We should really look at it very closely. We should be tireless in our efforts to find solutions because there is such despair and hopelessness among our young people. The member for Newcastle ( Mr Allan Morris) highlighted some terrible cases that he has come across. He touched me deeply when he spoke about the young women who had been to see him and the terrible cases of suicide. But young people can overcome some of these things. He spoke of some very positive instances where young women were prostitutes and were contemplating suicide but they were able to rebuild their lives and attend university and look forward to the future. He was right that we need to emphasise the youth aspects of it-the trauma and youth development-and I think that is very important to acknowledge. I have spoken on this topic on many occasions and today I would like to acknowledge the efforts of the House, particularly the previous chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs in producing the report Aspects of youth suicide. The report followed a very successful seminar that was held here earlier this year. I was not a member of the committee but I did gain quite a lot from attending on that particular day. The speakers were top rate and, as I mentioned, I have since had contact with one of the speakers, Associate Professor Pierre Baume. He has made a number of contributions in this area. It is an area that he has studied for a number of years. His extensive research has tended to emphasise the sociological factors that contribute to youth suicide. He believes that these can be divided into categories: the global aspects and the personal aspects. He mentioned a number of things, and a number of speakers have highlighted them-for instance, the high divorce rate. One cannot underestimate the effect of divorce. It is a devastating thing. What is more devastating, when people do split up, is that children sometimes feel that they are the direct cause of it. It is never talked through with young children, and it is not explained that they are not really the central issue in a divorce. Other areas were high youth and high female unemployment. Alcohol consumption, as the member for Leichhardt ( Mr Entsch) mentioned, is clearly a big problem. A number of speakers have raised the issue of unwanted pregnancies and the devastation this can have on people's lives not just in the immediate present but also well into the future. There is a trend these days not to attend church and not to be community or religion focused. One cannot underestimate the importance of those factors-when people have no-one to talk to-and having community support. There are some other facts that I would like to highlight, that come up frequently. The member for Leichhardt mentioned the rate of Aboriginal deaths by suicide. It is an area of grave concern. It is four times the rate of non-Aboriginals in Queensland. As I mentioned, for Thursday, 30 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 10423 every suicide, there are a number of suicides that are attempted-and these are 100 times greater. There is also the fact that there is a larger number of men who commit suicide than females. Blood alcohol levels and alcohol addictions clearly have a strong correlation with suicidal behaviour, particularly when you talk about binge drinking, which tends to occur mainly in summer. That was something that was highlighted at the recent breakfast that I hosted. These particular bouts of binge drinking occur in summer, and the rates of suicide are higher in summer. Professor Baume mentioned that we needed to put more preventive measures in place. But then he highlighted that we need to be particularly concerned-and he quoted studies that go back 30 or so years-because sometimes if you do put in too many prevention measures, or not the right prevention measures, suicide rates actually go up in schools where they have had prevention measures. He emphasised that there was a greater need to put these measures in place when people reach young adulthood, rather than at schools. That was quite an interesting revelation. I was quite amazed when he made that particular revelation. The main problems are definitely in the relationship area. I feel that young men do not mature as quickly as young women. Most of the problems are on a very personal level and they compound the situation. Things like the loss or death of a family friend, as I have mentioned, and break-up of relationships clearly come into the equation, particularly with young males when they are not able to deal with the sense of rejection and loss. We need to spend a lot more money on relationship counselling and dealing with those sorts of issues as well because they are clearly a problem when people are not able to deal with the break-up of a relationship or with grief issues. The importance of these factors is seen in the results of a youth forum in my area, in Redcliffe. Those forums will be continuing. Whilst forums like these are very important to identify problems and suggest solutions, it is important that all levels in the community combine and cooperate to follow through in working out strategies and implementing programs to help realise these solutions. The federal government has taken some steps, and they are to be commended, particularly in respect to the youth suicide issue. Upwards of $31 million is being spent on the national youth suicide prevention strategy, and they are very real and positive steps. Also, there is a provision of $6 million to states and territories to improve access in rural and remote areas to counselling; $6 million is being committed to Lifeline and Kids Helpline; and $3 million is being provided for programs for parents. And let's not underestimate the benefit of parents. We all take an individual responsibility when we have children to ensure that they are brought up in the correct manner as far as their physical needs are concerned and their schooling. But psychological nurturing and self-esteem are just as important. I know that negativity can be one of the greatest downfalls of any young person. We do need to nurture and look after our young people. All the research that I have seen on overseas countries and the incidence of suicide-and, clearly, Australia and New Zealand seem to have the highest rates in the industrialised worIdpoint to the factor of cultural and family influence. It is no coincidence when you see European countries with lower levels of youth suicide. One has to detect from that: is the family environment such that it does not encourage suicide? What is being done culturally in these countries that prevents suicide? Is it a stronger family situation? Is it the role of the 10424 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 30 October 1997 extended family? We cannot underestimate how important family influences and upbringing are in this particular issue. The previous Minister for Family Services( Mrs Moylan) best summed it up in June this year, when she launched the national youth suicide program, when she said: When so many of our young people are dying by their own hand through despair, desperation, frustration, or loneliness, it is a problem that demands national attention and national action. The recommendations of the committee's report are that developments in the effective service delivery of these programs and strategies will be based on positive and up-to-date information. The integration of suicide research is needed to ensure that grants are used effectively. There has to be some sort of consistency and accuracy in data collection in Australia. It is very disturbing when you see that there is no national database for suicide, and that the statistics are very sketchily collected and are very ad hoc. We really need to look at focusing on that. If we know the extent of the problem that we are dealing with, we can deal with it much more effectively. I emphasise the need for greater research and figures in this area. The federal government has shown that it is prepared to support and assist those who are at risk and are classified as prime candidates for youth suicide. The fact that the committee advocates the constant review of Australia's suicide strategy emphasises the fact that the strategies and funding policies need to be continually monitored, and updated if necessary. I think that it is important that the information be provided, that it is designed to assist families and those at risk, and that it needs to be as readily and widely available as possible. Doctors, teachers, counsellors, representatives at all levels of government, and particularly young people, should have access not only to this relevant information but also to the contact details. This is particularly important for families in crisis. The solution to youth suicide is very complex and very sensitive and this government has made, and will make, a significant effort to listen to and address the needs of that part of our community which right at this very minute is crying out in loneliness and desperation. I think that the most important step, the next step-prevention-is going to be very much harder, and we really do need to emphasise it. Debate (on motion by Mr Anthony) adjourned.
